questions.thesisStatementHelp: Declara la posición principal de tu país y qué soluciones apoyas en 1-2 oraciones
questions.backgroundContextHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones introduciendo los antecedentes de este problema
questions.keyEventsDescriptionHelp: Convierte tu lista de eventos en 2-3 oraciones explicando qué sucedió
questions.currentSituationHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones sobre cómo están las cosas hoy
questions.positionStatement: Declara la posición de tu país claramente
questions.positionStatementHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones declarando la postura oficial de tu país sobre este tema
questions.positionReason1: Da tu primera razón para esta posición
questions.positionReason2: Da tu segunda razón para esta posición
questions.positionReasonHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones explicando por qué tu país tiene esta opinión
questions.pastActions: Describe las acciones pasadas de tu país sobre este tema
questions.pastActionsHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones sobre lo que tu país ya ha hecho
questions.solutionHelp: Escribe 1-2 oraciones describiendo una acción específica que la comunidad internacional debería tomar
questions.bulletPointHint: Presiona Enter para agregar un nuevo punto. Cada punto se convertirá en una oración separada en tu documento.
questions.introTopicSentence: Oración Temática: Capta la atención del lector
questions.introTopicSentenceHelp: Ejemplo: "Cada año, millones de personas son afectadas por [tema], convirtiéndolo en uno de los problemas más urgentes que enfrenta la comunidad internacional."
questions.introContext: Contexto: Explica por qué esto importa
questions.introContextHelp: Ejemplo: "Este problema impacta no solo a [grupos afectados] sino que también amenaza [implicaciones más amplias]."
questions.introThesis: Tesis: Declara la posición de tu país
questions.introThesisHelp: Ejemplo: "[País] cree que abordar este problema requiere [enfoque general] y está comprometido con [acción]."
questions.introPreviewHelp: Ejemplo: "Este documento examinará los antecedentes del problema, la posición de [País] y propondrá soluciones concretas para consideración del comité."
questions.bgTopicSentenceHelp: Ejemplo: "Comprender la historia de [tema] es esencial para desarrollar soluciones efectivas."
questions.bgEvidence: Evidencia: Presenta hechos y eventos clave
questions.bgEvidenceHelp: Ejemplo: "En [año], [evento] ocurrió, lo que llevó a [consecuencia]. Según [fuente], [estadística o hecho]."
questions.bgAnalysis: Análisis: Explica por qué esta evidencia importa
questions.bgAnalysisHelp: Ejemplo: "Estos eventos demuestran que [perspicacia]. Este patrón muestra que [análisis]."
questions.bgTransition: Transición: Conecta con la posición de tu país
questions.bgTransitionHelp: Ejemplo: "Dado este contexto, está claro por qué [País] ha tomado la postura de que [breve vista previa de posición]."
questions.posTopicSentenceHelp: Ejemplo: "[País] cree firmemente que [declaración clara de posición]."
questions.posEvidenceHelp: Ejemplo: "Esta posición se basa en [razón 1] y [razón 2]. La experiencia de [País] con [ejemplo relevante] demuestra esto."
questions.posAnalysis: Análisis: Muestra el compromiso de tu país
questions.posAnalysisHelp: Ejemplo: "[País] ya ha tomado acción mediante [acciones pasadas]. Esto demuestra nuestro compromiso con [objetivo]."
questions.posCounterargumentHelp: Ejemplo: "Algunas naciones argumentan que [opinión opuesta] porque [su razonamiento]."
questions.posRebuttalHelp: Ejemplo: "Sin embargo, [País] mantiene que [respuesta]. La evidencia muestra que [contra-evidencia]."
questions.solTopicSentenceHelp: Ejemplo: "Para abordar [tema], [País] propone las siguientes soluciones para consideración del comité."
questions.solSolutionFullHelp: Ejemplo: "Primero/Segundo/Tercero, [País] propone [acción específica]. Esto funcionaría mediante [explicación]. Esta solución aborda [aspecto específico del problema]."
questions.solImplementationHelp: Ejemplo: "Estas soluciones podrían implementarse a través de [mecanismo], con supervisión de [organismo]. [País] está preparado para [contribución de tu país]."
questions.conRestatementHelp: Ejemplo: "En conclusión, [País] reafirma su compromiso de abordar [tema] a través de [enfoque]."
questions.conSummaryHelp: Ejemplo: "Como se describe en este documento, [breve resumen de posición y soluciones]."
questions.conCallToAction: Llamado a la Acción: ¿Qué deben hacer los delegados?
questions.conCallToActionHelp: Ejemplo: "[País] insta a todos los estados miembros a unirse a nosotros en [acción]. Juntos, podemos [resultado deseado]."
questions.counterargumentsHelp: ¿Qué podrían decir los países que no están de acuerdo? Escribe 2-3 oraciones respondiendo a sus preocupaciones

WillPageMetadata.title: Will Ballis | JAMUN
WillPageMetadata.description: Will Ballis es Director de Mathletes en JAMUN. Graduado en Matemáticas de Duke University y educador dedicado, Will lidera nuestro programa de matemáticas con experiencia y compromiso.
WillPageMetadata.ogDescription: Will Ballis - Director de Mathletes en JAMUN.

WillPage.heroDescription: Líder apasionado. Educador dedicado. Will aporta profunda experiencia en razonamiento matemático y un compromiso con el desarrollo de la próxima generación de pensadores matemáticos.
WillPage.storyParagraph1: Will estudió Matemáticas en Duke University, donde desarrolló tanto un enfoque riguroso de resolución de problemas como una profunda apreciación por la elegancia del razonamiento matemático. Sus estudios abarcaron teoría de números, álgebra, geometría y combinatoria.
WillPage.storyParagraph2: Más allá de su formación académica, Will se ha dedicado a la educación. Entiende que la habilidad matemática no es fija—se desarrolla a través de la práctica, la mentoría y los desafíos correctos en el momento adecuado. Su enfoque combina altas expectativas con apoyo genuino.
WillPage.storyParagraph3: En JAMUN, Will supervisa nuestro programa Mathletes, diseñando currículos y entrenamientos que ayudan a los estudiantes a desarrollar bases matemáticas sólidas. Bajo su liderazgo, el programa ha crecido para servir a estudiantes de múltiples niveles de habilidad, construyendo confianza y capacidad en cada participante.
WillPage.trait1Description: Will adopta un enfoque reflexivo para construir programas que perduren. Se centra en el crecimiento sostenible, asegurando que lo que construimos hoy continúe sirviendo a los estudiantes en los años venideros.
WillPage.trait2Description: Los conceptos complejos requieren explicaciones claras. Will ha desarrollado la capacidad de desglosar problemas difíciles en pasos comprensibles sin sacrificar la precisión matemática.
WillPage.trait3Description: Will trata los recursos organizacionales con cuidado. Toma decisiones con miras a la eficiencia y el impacto, asegurando que cada dólar y cada hora de tiempo voluntario cuente.
WillPage.quote: Las matemáticas te enseñan a pensar. Las habilidades de resolución de problemas, el razonamiento lógico, la capacidad de trabajar en algo difícil—todo esto se transfiere a todo lo demás que los estudiantes harán.

ReferralPageMetadata.title: Bring JAMUN Programs to Your School
ReferralPageMetadata.description: School referral guide for JAMUN's Model UN, Mock Trial, and Mathletes programs. Free academic competition programs for grades 5-8.

ReferralPage.headerSubtitle: FREE, standards-aligned academic competition programs for grades 5-8
ReferralPage.headerOrg: The Junior Assembly of the Model United Nations is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit providing affordable Model UN, Mock Trial, and Mathletes programs. 100% youth-led. 500+ students impacted across 30+ schools.
ReferralPage.modelun_description: Model United Nations (MUN) is an educational simulation where students role-play as delegates to the United Nations. Each student represents a country and must research that nation's positions on global issues, write formal position papers, deliver speeches, negotiate with other delegates in structured caucuses, and collaboratively draft resolutions. MUN develops diplomatic skills, public speaking, persuasive writing, critical thinking, and global awareness. JAMUN is looking for schools that want to bring this transformative program to their students!
ReferralPage.modelun_objective1: Research assigned countries' history, politics, economy, and foreign policy using multiple sources
ReferralPage.modelun_objective2: Write position papers supporting a country's stance with evidence and counterarguments
ReferralPage.modelun_objective3: Deliver formal opening speeches and points of information before committees
ReferralPage.modelun_objective4: Negotiate and debate in moderated and unmoderated caucuses using parliamentary procedure
ReferralPage.modelun_objective5: Draft, amend, and vote on resolutions addressing global challenges
ReferralPage.modelun_objective6: Attend low-cost conferences and compete for Best Delegate, Outstanding Delegate, and Honorable Mention awards
ReferralPage.modelun_objective7: Build coalitions across countries with differing perspectives to find compromise solutions
ReferralPage.modelun_schoolReq: Schools must identify a faculty advisor or contact person who coordinates the program. This includes recruiting students, securing a meeting space for practice sessions, communicating with JAMUN staff to schedule conferences, and supporting student attendance at events. Schools should hold a minimum of three practice sessions (45 minutes to one hour each) in advance of each conference so students are prepared for committee. The contact person should meet with JAMUN staff at least twice before the season begins and be responsive to email for smooth coordination. Schools should encourage participation from diverse student groups — no prior experience or academic prerequisites are required.
ReferralPage.modelun_scheduling: JAMUN holds one conference in the fall and one in the spring. Our next conference will be April 25 and 26. Schools should express interest by August to secure spots for the fall conference. JAMUN will confirm scheduling 4-6 weeks prior to each conference. Practice sessions should begin well in advance — we recommend at least three sessions before each conference. Schools interested in spring-only participation should reach out by December.
ReferralPage.modelun_financial: Core program resources, training materials, and weekly session support are provided at no cost. Conference registration fees are low-cost, typically $15-25 per student. Grants are available covering up to 100% of conference costs including registration, travel, and materials for qualifying students. There is no application fee for grants, and decisions are returned within 2-3 weeks.
ReferralPage.modelun_provides1: Comprehensive delegate training materials (parliamentary procedure, position paper guides, speech frameworks)
ReferralPage.modelun_provides2: Volunteer mentors to lead weekly practice sessions at your school
ReferralPage.modelun_provides3: Conference registration coordination and logistical support
ReferralPage.modelun_provides4: Background guides and country research resources for each committee
ReferralPage.modelun_provides5: Grant application assistance covering up to 100% of conference costs
ReferralPage.modelun_provides6: Ongoing support: a JAMUN staff member is available throughout the season to ensure your program runs smoothly
ReferralPage.mocktrial_description: Mock Trial is a competitive simulation where students re-enact courtroom trials. Students take on roles as prosecuting and defense attorneys and witnesses, arguing a fictional case before a panel of judges. Students analyze case materials and evidence, prepare opening and closing statements, conduct direct and cross-examinations, develop witness characters, and argue objections using formal rules of evidence. Mock Trial develops persuasive speaking, analytical reasoning, civic literacy, and performance confidence. This program directly supports the CPS 8th Grade Constitution requirement.
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective1: Analyze trial case packets including witness affidavits, evidence exhibits, and applicable laws
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective2: Prepare persuasive opening statements that outline the theory of the case
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective3: Conduct direct examinations to build a case through witness testimony
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective4: Conduct cross-examinations to challenge opposing witnesses and expose weaknesses
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective5: Play witness roles with developed backstories, motivations, and character consistency
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective6: Argue objections (relevance, hearsay, speculation, leading) using rules of evidence in real time
ReferralPage.mocktrial_objective7: Deliver closing arguments synthesizing evidence and testimony into a compelling narrative
ReferralPage.mocktrial_schoolReq: Schools must identify a faculty advisor or contact person who coordinates the program. This includes recruiting students, securing a meeting space for practice sessions, and supporting student attendance at competitions. The contact person should communicate with JAMUN staff regularly and attend at least one planning meeting before the season. A classroom or open space that can simulate a courtroom layout is ideal. No legal background is required — JAMUN provides all training.
ReferralPage.mocktrial_scheduling: Competition season runs August through April. The case will be released over the summer so teams can begin preparation early. Practice schedules can vary by school, but we recommend at least 3 hours of practice — weekly sessions work well. Schools should express interest by July to be included in the season. JAMUN will coordinate competition dates and logistics throughout the year.
ReferralPage.mocktrial_financial: Core program, all case materials, evidence packets, and training resources are provided at no cost. Competition fees are affordable. Grants are available covering up to 100% of competition costs for qualifying students. There is no application fee for grants.
ReferralPage.mocktrial_provides1: Complete case materials: witness affidavits, evidence exhibits, stipulations, and applicable rules
ReferralPage.mocktrial_provides2: Volunteer coaches trained in trial advocacy to lead weekly practice sessions
ReferralPage.mocktrial_provides4: Guides for objection types, examination techniques, and courtroom procedures
ReferralPage.mocktrial_provides5: Grant application assistance covering up to 100% of competition costs
ReferralPage.mocktrial_provides6: A JAMUN staff member attends competitions and is available throughout the season for support
ReferralPage.mathletes_description: Mathletes is JAMUN's competitive mathematics program — and it's an incredible opportunity for students to challenge themselves, grow their confidence, and discover the thrill of mathematical problem-solving. Through weekly practice sessions, students develop speed, accuracy, and reasoning across number theory, algebra, geometry, probability, and counting. Practice includes individual sprint rounds, paired target rounds, collaborative team rounds, and head-to-head countdown rounds. JAMUN's Mathletes competitions are designed to be exciting, accessible, and rewarding — building computational fluency, logical reasoning, pattern recognition, and the confidence to tackle tough problems. All skill levels are welcome.
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective1: Solve challenging competition-style problems across number theory, algebra, geometry, and probability
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective2: Practice mental math strategies and computational shortcuts for speed rounds
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective3: Work in teams on collaborative problem-solving challenges (Team Round format)
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective4: Prepare for JAMUN's competition format across sprint, target, team, and countdown rounds
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective5: Compete in four JAMUN Mathletes competitions throughout the season, earning individual and team recognition
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective6: Build mathematical intuition through puzzles, games, and pattern-based reasoning
ReferralPage.mathletes_objective7: Develop strategies for multi-step problems, estimation, and proof-based reasoning
ReferralPage.mathletes_schoolReq: Schools must identify a math teacher or faculty advisor who coordinates the program. This includes recruiting students (all skill levels welcome — unlimited participation), securing a meeting space for weekly 1-1.5 hour practice sessions, and supporting student attendance at competitions. A room with a whiteboard or projector is ideal. No advanced math background is required from the advisor — JAMUN provides curriculum and mentors.
ReferralPage.mathletes_scheduling: Competition season runs August through April, with four JAMUN Mathletes competitions spread across the year. Schools should express interest by July to be included in the season. Weekly practice sessions can begin as early as August. JAMUN coordinates all competition dates, registration, and logistics — schools just need to show up and compete!
ReferralPage.mathletes_financial: Core program, all practice materials, and curriculum resources are provided at no cost. Competition registration fees are affordable. Grants are available covering up to 100% of competition costs for qualifying students.
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides1: Practice problem sets organized by topic and difficulty, aligned to competition formats
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides2: Volunteer mentors to lead weekly practice sessions at your school
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides3: Competition registration coordination and event logistics for all four competitions
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides4: Formula reference sheets, strategy guides, and practice problem sets
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides5: Grant application assistance covering up to 100% of competition costs
ReferralPage.mathletes_provides6: Ongoing curriculum support and a JAMUN staff member available throughout the season

ReferralPage.printOrg: Junior Assembly of the Model United Nations

SupportersPage.heroDescription: JAMUN's mission to make academic competitions accessible and affordable wouldn't be possible without the generous support of our community partners and advisors. Together, we're empowering the next generation of leaders.
SupportersPage.partnersSubtitle: These organizations share our commitment to making academic competitions accessible to all students.
SupportersPage.partner1Description: The nation's largest organization dedicated to empowering students to stay in school and achieve in life, serving over 2 million students annually across 3,500+ schools.
SupportersPage.boardSubtitle: Our advisory board brings decades of experience in education, nonprofit leadership, and youth development.
SupportersPage.boardMember1Bio: A seasoned senior business leader and youth advocate, Jenifer is passionate about developing future leaders. She brings deep expertise in operations, adult learning, and organizational development to help guide JAMUN's growth.
SupportersPage.boardMember2Bio: With 40+ years of marketing and business advisory experience, Howard is a professional board member who helps organizations grow strategically. He advises JAMUN on business development and long-term sustainability.
SupportersPage.ctaDescription: Whether through partnership, donation, or advisory service, your support helps us make academic competitions accessible to every middle school student.
